article.description:
Oregon coach Ernie Kent would have liked to
know that James Davis was just one 3-pointer shy of the school
record. He would have made him go for it.
article.headline: Davis hits seven 3-pointers as Ducks roll Grambling
article.linkText: Davis' seven 3s get No. 9 Oregon off and running
article.story: EUGENE, Ore. (AP) -- Oregon coach Ernie Kent would have liked to know that James Davis was just one 3-pointer shy of the school record. He would have made him go for it. Davis had 21 points on seven 3-pointers as Oregon (No. 9 ESPN/USA Today; No. 10 Associated Press) opened its season with a 97-52 rout of Grambling State in the John Thompson Foundation Challenge on Sunday night. Davis, who attempted 12 3-pointers, nearly matched Oregon record-holders Orlando Williams, who made eight 3-pointers against Wisconsin-Green Bay in 1994, and Jamal Lawrence, who also had eight against Stanford in 1997. ''You guys should have told me that,'' said Kent, who thought Davis took only one bad shot the whole game. ''You should have sent a message down.'' Davis was philosophical about his night. ''It's an up-and-down game,'' he said. ''Everybody is going to have their day.'' Luke Ridnour had 21 points and nine assists, and Luke Jackson added 14 points for Oregon, which will face California State-Northridge -- a winner over Jacksonville earlier Sunday -- in the title game Monday night. It was the 17th consecutive victory for the defending Pacific-10 Conference champions in McArthur Court, as well as their 11th consecutive season-opening victory. Grambling State (0-2) was coming off a 99-46 defeat against Georgetown on Friday night. The Tigers were equally overwhelmed by the Ducks, who led by as many as 54 points in the second half. The Tigers were led by William McDonald with 17 points and nine rebounds, but they were hampered with just 23 percent shooting from the floor and 25 turnovers. But Grambling State simply could not keep up with Oregon's savvy passing and superior speed. ''Certainly, they are on a different level than we are,'' Tigers coach Larry Wright said. ''They play the game the way it should be played, and it's beautiful to watch.'' Grambling State kept it close through the first 10 minutes, but then Oregon began to pull away. James Davis' pass to Robert Johnson for the dunk made it 21-13 with 8:53 to go. Oregon led by 22 points in the first half and took a 42-22 lead into halftime. It was all Oregon from then on, with the Ducks going up 67-27 on Davis' 3-pointer. Before the game, Oregon unfurled its 2002 Pac-10 championship banner from the rafters of Mac Court to a standing ovation from the crowd, which included golfer Casey Martin. The Ducks finished 26-9 overall and 14-4 in the Pac-10, capping their season with a trip to the NCAA tournament were they lost an Elite Eight game to Kansas. ''It feels good to finally get this season going and get some confidence,'' Davis said. ''We're getting into a good rhythm.'' Grambling State finished last season 9-19 overall and 7-11 in the Southwestern Athletic Conference. California State-Northridge beat Jacksonville 67-55, setting up the consolation game Monday between Grambling State and Jacksonville.
